Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploring the geography of sodium as a catalyst in terrestrial communities and ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Essential services performed by Earth's ecosystems, such as decomposing detritus into nutrients, transforming plants into meat, creating and aerating fertile soil, arise from the combined actions of millions of organisms. Each of these organisms, from bacteria to butterflies to bison, best contribute to these services when they consume a healthy diet, which includes access to minerals, especially sodium. Sodium is a critical mineral for ecosystems because plants are generally low in sodium but the things that eat them, from fungi to grasshoppers, require it to grow and reproduce. Thus every plant eater must search out, harvest, and hang onto quantities of sodium, and will go to extremes eating carcasses, soil, and urine, to get that quota. Moreover, sodium is not uniformly distributed on the landscape. It falls as dilute ocean water near the coasts, it clings to clay soils but is leached from sandy soils, and it is distributed by the truckload to keep snowy roads free from ice. This project combines these two facts, that sodium is potentially one of the most important drivers of the health of plant consumers, and that sodium is geographically patchy, to predict the abundance and services of plant consumers across the North American continent. This research should lead to better prediction of such disparate phenomena as why grasshoppers are bigger crop pests in one county than another; why carbon is better stored in inland soils than those near the ocean; and why termite damage claims are centered along the Gulf Coast of the U.S. and up into the Mid-Atlantic states.

To evaluate this proposition, the project combines two methods. The first maps the distribution of sodium across and within North American ecosystems and focuses on the easily accessible and widespread grasslands, old fields, and roadsides, and the invertebrates that live in them. The goal in Year 1 is to explore the basic hypothesis that as soil supplies of sodium increase - due to deposition from the ocean, high clay content, or because they are salted every winter - plants will not be affected but the animals that eat them (and the predators that eat the plant consumers) will. Thus the first year will generate a map of the abundance and activity of invertebrates above and belowground, and the degree to which both track sodium supply (and other nutrients). Then, in Year 2 and 3, these correlations will be put to the test experimentally in 6 grasslands from the central and eastern U.S. At each grassland, 50 meter square plots will be fertilized with a dilute sodium concentrations mimicking the slightly salty rainfall of the island of Puerto Rico; smaller plots will receive sodium mimicking that deposited on a regular basis by every animal as urine. By carefully tracking where the sodium goes, and how it boosts the numbers and activity of invertebrates, the project will test how animal health and vigor across North America is influenced by sodium supply. By examining how pollinators, herbivores, and detritivores respond, the project will test the transformative idea that sodium is a catalyst for ecosystem services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

 

Ranchers and hunters have long known that herbivores need sodium in their diets. Indeed, a well-placed salt lick not only attracts cattle and deer, but also a whole host of other wildlife. Naturally occurring salt licks are some of the best places to see many species of birds in one place. And, anecdotally, it seems likely that the best place to see a moose in New England is near a bumpy highway, where salt spills out of the back of a salt truck preparing the roads for the next big snow storm.

 

Despite the general knowledge that all animals need salt in their diets (it is necessary for some key physiological functions), only recently has it become clear to ecologists that sodium limitation might have cascading consequences in communities and ecosystems. Work on insect herbivores and detritivores has also shown that enriching plots with Na increases the abundance of insect herbivores in grasslands in the US, termite abundance and activity in Amazonian forests, leafcutter ant herbivory in Costa Rica and ant activity across the Tropics and North America. But the question we sought to ask was whether the effects on these sodium-limited organisms influenced a whole suite of community processes and ecosystem functions.

 

The general approach was to experimentally increase sodium availability in numerous grassland and meadow ecosystems throughout the US. This allowed us to understand how climate and other factors might interact with sodium limitation to influence community processes and ecosystem function.

 

Some early results indicated that ant communities were limited by sodium, and as temperature increased they were even more limited (Prather et al. 2018) because as temperature goes up, metabolic rate goes up, and so the loss of salt. We also found that aboveground and belowground invertebrates responded slightly differently to sodium amendments: aboveground invertebrates tended to respond more to nitrogen and phosphorous additions, but belowground invertebrates responded to sodium, nitrogen, and phosphorous (Kaspari et al. 2015). Across 54 sites, we found even strong evidence of sodium limitation: plots to which we added additional sodium saw the abundance of insect herbivores increase by 45% (Welti et al. 2019) and the structure of arthropod food webs altered (Welti et al. 2020).

 

Work that we're just finishing up now is being led by two undergraduate students. One of the projects examines how sodium limitation affects browsing by deer and in turn, ants. The other project asks whether sodium-enriched nectar might increase visitation rate by pollinators. It turns out that the answers to both questions is yes. Deer eat more plant biomass if the plants are sprayed with salt water; the plots with less biomass then become hotspots (literally) for ants because they are warmer and sunnier locations for nests. Similarly, if we artificially add sodium to nectar, more pollinators are attracted. So it could be the case that some plants actively spike their nectar with sodium in order to attract pollinators.
